Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: Exploring gender differences in effort before competition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).<br/><br/>Competitions are increasingly prevalent in the global labor market, where winners are disproportionately rewarded. Prior work has suggested that gender differences in competitiveness, with women being less competitive, on average, than men, may contribute to persistent gender disparities in labor market outcomes. As a result, much of the research on gender differences in competitions has focused on i) understanding the sources of the gender difference and ii) designing interventions to encourage women to compete more. Less consideration, however, has been paid to whether and how women and men may differently respond to competitions. Because past research suggests that women are less confident and more risk-averse than men, and this may, in part, explain their reluctance to compete, women may spend more time preparing for competitions when they do compete. The first aim of this research is to examine whether women spend more time than men preparing for tasks where their performance will be evaluated, and specifically, when their performance is being evaluated against a competitor. The second aim of this dissertation is to test whether beliefs about gender differences in performance on a task, which have previously been shown to affect confidence and performance, also affect gender differences in preparation before competition. Experiments are conducted using an online marketplace, where participants are paid for their performance on various tasks. Understanding how individuals respond to competitive situations may help address economic disparities across groups, including persistent gender differences in labor market outcomes. If, for instance, competitions exacerbate gender differences in the amount of effort exerted (i.e., preparing) before performance, this may affect women’s labor output, career advancement, their ability to achieve a satisfying work-life balance, and even their decision to enter or stay in competitive environments. As this is a new area of research, there are many promising and exciting avenues for future exploration, all of which have the potential to inform policies that promote greater gender equality.<br/><br/>The researchers hypothesize that women will spend more time preparing than men, especially before competitions, in part because they are, on average, less risk-seeking and confident than men. We will also test boundary conditions of the anticipated interaction by examining how beliefs about gender differences in performance shape decisions to prepare before competitions. The researchers experimentally test these hypotheses in an online marketplace where participant performance on the task is incentivized. In the first experiment they manipulate whether participants will be paid according to a competitive payment scheme (i.e., incentives for their performance are higher, but they must outperform another individual in the study to earn anything for their performance) or a non-competitive payment scheme (i.e., incentives for their performance are guaranteed, but lower). Participants will have the option to complete an unlimited amount of practice problems that closely resemble the incentivized task before entering the incentivized stage of the study. In the second experiment, they manipulate participants’ beliefs about gender differences in performance on a task under a competitive payment scheme. Specifically, participants are randomly assigned to learn about results from a scientific article that either i) point to a male advantage or ii) point to a female advantage on the task. Similar to the first experiment, participants have the option to complete an unlimited amount of practice problems before moving on to the competition. Across both studies, the main dependent variable of interest is amount of time spent preparing for the incentivized task. It is predicted that women will choose to prepare more than men before a competition, especially when they are led to believe that males may have a performance advantage. The proposed work will advance knowledge by providing the foundation for a fruitful line of work focused on how men and women differently respond to competitions, and its possible economic ramifications for women.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Competitions are becoming more common in the global job market, and winners often receive disproportionate rewards. Previous studies have shown that gender differences in competitiveness may contribute to ongoing gender disparities in labor market outcomes, as women tend to be less competitive than men, on average. Specifically, when given the choice between a competitive payment scheme, where only the winner is paid, and a piece-rate payment scheme, where payments are based on individual performance, a greater proportion of men than women choose the competitive option. Researchers have focused on understanding the causes of this gender difference and designing interventions to encourage women to participate in more competitions. However, there has been less attention given to understanding how men and women respond in competitive environments, which is crucial for addressing labor disparities in the workplace. In this study, we explore the effects of competitions on gender differences in practice. 

Existing research suggests that women are less confident and more risk-averse than men, which explains their hesitancy to compete. Our preliminary research also found that when women are informed that their performance will be evaluated for monetary earnings, they tend to invest more time in practicing for the task compared to men. In other words, we found initial evidence for a gender difference in practice. The current project aims to replicate this gender difference in a larger sample and examine whether it is magnified when performance is assessed against a competitor rather than individually. We hypothesize that the gender difference in practice will be greater when participants are assigned to a competitive payment scheme compared to a piece-rate payment scheme.

We randomly assigned 3980 participants from an online marketplace to have their performance on a multiplication task assessed under either a competitive payment scheme or a piece-rate payment scheme. All participants were informed about the task and the assigned payment scheme. They were then given an opportunity for unlimited practice before the task assessment began. Practice was measured in several ways: 1) the decision to practice or not, 2) the number of practice problems attempted, and 3) the total time spent practicing. Additionally, we explored participants' beliefs about which gender would practice more in the study.

Regardless of risk aversion, confidence levels, and the assigned condition, we found a significant gender difference in the choice to practice. Overall, 51.26% of women chose to practice, while only 37.81% of men did the same. Women also completed a greater number of practice problems, engaged in more practice rounds, and spent more time practicing compared to men. Contrary to expectations, we found no evidence to suggest that the competitive payment scheme increased practice in either men or women. These findings suggest that women tend to prepare more for tasks, regardless of whether their performance is being evaluated individually or against a competitor. We also used monetary incentives to elicit participants' beliefs about gender differences in task preparation. The majority (59.57%) of participants believed that women were more likely to practice for the task than men, while only a small percentage (less than 5%) believed that men would be more likely to practice. Only 36% of participants believed that men and women would practice the same amount.

Our findings provide compelling evidence for a gender difference in practice, with women practicing more than men, on average. Future research should investigate how practice influences performance and earnings. Presently, it is unclear whether women in our study are over-practicing, men are under-practicing, or both.  Over-practicing may result in opportunity costs that potentially contribute to the gender wage gap.  On the other hand, under-practicing among men may also have its own costs. While there is a gender wage gap that favors men, it is also important to acknowledge a widening achievement gap, where men are falling behind women in test scores and educational attainment. Exploring the extent to which the gender difference in practice contributes to both the gender wage gap and the gender achievement gap is important.
